title: Given a scenario, configure Microsoft Windows networking features on a client/desktop.
content:
🖧 Workgroup vs. Domain Setup

Workgroup:

  • Peer-to-peer networking
  • Best for small networks (under 10 computers)
  • Each computer manages its own users and permissions

Domain:

  • Centralized management via a Domain Controller (Active Directory)
  • Used in businesses for enhanced security and centralized policies
  • Users log into the domain instead of individual PCs

🔁 Shared Resources:

  • Printers: Network-accessible shared printers
  • File Servers: Centralized data storage
  • Mapped Drives: Assign a drive letter (like Z:) to shared folders

🔥 Local OS Firewall Settings

  • Application Restrictions: Allow or block programs through the firewall
  • Configuration: Customize inbound/outbound rules, set different behavior for private/public networks
  • Access via Control Panel > Windows Defender Firewall

🌐 Client Network Configuration

  • IP Address: Identifies each device (e.g., 192.168.1.10)
  • DNS: Resolves domain names to IP addresses
  • Subnet Mask: Defines the network portion (e.g., 255.255.255.0)
  • Gateway: Router IP that routes external traffic
  • Static vs. Dynamic: Static is manual, Dynamic is assigned by DHCP

🔌 Establish Network Connections

  • VPN: Secure, encrypted remote connection
  • Wireless: Wi-Fi with SSID and WPA2/WPA3 password
  • Wired: Ethernet for stability and speed
  • WWAN: Cellular (4G/5G) network access

⚙️ Other Features

  • Proxy Settings: Routes internet traffic via proxy server for security/filtering
  • Public vs. Private Network: Public restricts sharing; Private allows it
  • File Explorer Navigation: Access shared resources using \\PC-NAME\SharedFolder
  • Metered Connections: Limits background data usage and updates on limited networks
